context.text: In the opinion filed with the clerk today, we agree with the Fourth Circuit that the determination of whether an exchange has the effect of a dividend should be made by treating the payment of boot as though it came from the acquiring corporation in the context of a redemption immediately following the corporate reorganization.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: In an opinion filed with the clerk, we hold that the interest of a private citizen in non-disclosure of a wrap sheet is the sort of personal privacy interest that congress intended exemption 7(c) to protect.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: We further hold that such an invasion of privacy is not warranted under the Act when the request seeks no official information about a government agency that merely records that the government happens to be storing.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The judgment below is accordingly reversed.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Justice Blackmun has filed an opinion concurring the judgment in which Justice Brennan has joined.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But I return to what I said in response to Justice Scalia's question, which is that our first submission is that under Hope, under Natural Gas Pipeline, under the earlier decisions of this Court as well, there has never been a suggestion by the Court that a ratemaking body, whether it be a state legislature or a public utility commission, can pick and choose among ratemaking methods so that it produces the result that it wants to achieve.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: This is a case in which the Public Utility Commission follows, generally speaking, the original cost-prudent investment method of fixing rates.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist

context.text: As I recall, the Court in Caldwell said that the reference to the waiver issue in the prevailing opinion is somewhat cryptic, but then went on to note that the Michigan Supreme Court had requested briefs on the Constitutional issue, had requested oral argument, and had in fact attempted to decide it, four to four.

context.speaker: Kimball R. Anderson
context.text: So I can't agree with Your Honor that the decision was crystal clear, because Justice Marshall did note that the Mississippi Supreme Court had referred to the waiver issue, and that the Court's reference, as he put it, was "somewhat cryptic".

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, assuming that we made a clear holding, that procedural grounds are subject to the Michigan Long, v. Long rule in direct review cases, if we apply it in the context of a habeas proceeding, I assume that in most of the cases such as Justice Scalia puts, where there is simply a one-line order affirmed, we won't need cause and prejudice anymore because we simply rely on a presumption that procedural bar was not invoked?

context.speaker: Kimball R. Anderson
context.text: Well, I have urged in my briefs, and here today, that you don't adopt that presumption because that presumption is contrary to the rationale set forth in Michigan v. Long, and it also runs the risk that the Federal District Court is simply going to guess wrong at the meaning of the State Court, and fundamental rights will be lost simply because the State Court's opinion was obscured.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, you mention the Illinois practice, really as an empirical matter.

context.speaker: Robert F. Vacchelli
context.text: If brewers lower their prices in New York, they must keep that for six months.

context.speaker: Robert F. Vacchelli
context.text: That is certainly a deterrent to their ability to target prices throughout the State of New York.

context.speaker: Robert F. Vacchelli
context.text: And I think this is--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, I guess the point is, as Justice Stevens' question illustrates, you say, well, Connecticut is really eliminated... a rigidly controlled market, but it still abolishes... or it still prohibits quantity discounts.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And that's one of the whole problems in this case.

context.speaker: Robert F. Vacchelli
context.text: --Well, I... I'm not sure that the ability or disability to give quantity discounts has much to do with the competitiveness of the... of the Connecticut industry since the net effect is that we do have lower prices in Connecticut now.

context.speaker: Martin W. Hoffman

context.speaker: John Wesley Hall, Jr.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: These cases concern the constitutionality of the Sentencing Reformat of 1984, and that Act created the United States Sentencing Commission as an independent body in the Judicial Branch with power to promulgate binding sentencing guidelines.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: Guidelines have been issued and they are challenged here.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: And because of that conflict in the great importance of the issues in the administration of this countrys criminal law, we granted the respective petitions of defendant, Mistretta, and of the United States for certiorari before judgment in the Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: In an opinion filed with the Clerk today, a too long opinion I have here, we hold that the sentencing guidelines are constitutional and specifically, that Congress did not delegate excessive legislative power to the Commission and did not violate the separation of powers principled by placing the Commission in the Judicial Branch or by requiring federal judges to serve on the Commission and to share their authority with non-judges or by empowering the President to appoint Commission members and to remove them for cause.

context.text: It's a very difficult situation.

context.speaker: Frank K. Heap
context.text: It has never reached this Court before.

context.speaker: Frank K. Heap
context.text: The Court has come very close in a couple of cases to address this question, but it's... my research has revealed this is the first time the issue has been directly before this Court.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: To come back to Justice O'Connor's question, it's not really an Article III problem unless you think that Article III requires complete diversity.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: We've never held that, have we?

context.speaker: Frank K. Heap
context.text: I think--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Well, 54(b) really only speaks of, of when not, not how.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: It says may direct entry as to one or more, but fewer than all, only upon an express determination, that there is no just reason for delay and upon express direction for the entry of judgment.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I mean, it seems to me what it's talking about is you can't do it sooner as to some than, than as to others.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But I don't think it really speaks to whether you can enter a separate judgment for each of them simultaneously, which is what Justice Stevens is asking about.

context.speaker: Gordon Lee Garrett, Jr.
context.text: Well, I think that's true.

context.speaker: Gordon Lee Garrett, Jr.
context.text: But, of course, Rule 54(b) really relates to prejudgment and pre-verdict matters.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the Court in number 87-1201 Osterneck versus Ernst & Whinney will be announced by Justice Kennedy.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: This case number 87-1201 comes to us on writ of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: After receiving a judgment partially in their favor, the petitioners filed a motion for prejudgment interest.

context.speaker: Kenneth Kimerling
context.text: I didn't--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, I'm just really following up on--

context.speaker: Kenneth Kimerling
context.text: --[inaudible].

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: --Justice O'Connor's question.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: You say that Wilson v. Garcia doesn't apply if a state has a general personal injury statute of limitations of one year?

context.speaker: Kenneth Kimerling
context.text: I... I think that there is a three-step process--

context.speaker: Kenneth Kimerling
context.text: Obviously, our position is whatever you choose, we win.

context.speaker: Kenneth Kimerling
context.text: I think that's the... but if we choose that, I don't think not on a... on a... on a cynical basis, but I think on a... on a very consistent basis, that one year simply doesn't take into account the practicalities and the purposes underlying Section 1983.

context.speaker: Kenneth Kimerling
context.text: And going back to--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But as Justice O'Connor says, no choice available to us will produce that happy state of affairs anyway.

context.speaker: Kenneth Kimerling
context.text: --I'm sorry.

context.speaker: Kenneth Kimerling
context.text: I don't understand your question.

context.speaker: Kenneth Kimerling
context.text: So, in some subsequent cases, you may be faced with the question as to whether one year is long enough.

context.speaker: Kenneth Kimerling
context.text: And you'll have to reach that question in those cases, but you don't have to reach it here if you decide that the general remedy for personal injury claims is... is the appropriate one.

context.speaker: Kenneth Kimerling
context.text: But--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Mr. Kimerling, are you suggesting that our search for simplicity that Justice O'Connor thought was illusory, really is illusory if we're going to get this issue next?

context.speaker: Kenneth Kimerling
context.text: --No, not at all.

context.speaker: Kenneth Kimerling
context.text: I think... I think that... that you've gone far down the road to certainty and uniformity.

context.speaker: Kenneth Kimerling
context.text: But if your First Amendment rights are violated, that claim gets extinguished in one year.

context.speaker: Kenneth Kimerling
context.text: That doesn't make sense.

context.speaker: Kenneth Kimerling
context.text: That's inconsistent it seems to me.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Do you happen to know... in her dissent in the Wilson case Justice O'Connor pointed out there had been several bills introduced in Congress in recent years to prescribe a single statute of limitations for 1983.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Do you know what periods of limitations most of those bills--

context.speaker: Kenneth Kimerling
context.text: I... I... I researched some of them, and I didn't try to figure out which ones... they went... depending on who introduced them, they were short or long.

context.text: In Evitts v. Lucey, no appeal was ever taken, was there?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: So nothing was done.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Here, I think, as Justice Scalia points out, the lawyer did something.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: You say it was wrong, and grossly inadequate, but I don't think that's the same thing as just saying that he never... he wasn't even there.

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: It should be, just as Justice Scalia suggested, it just don't... no error at all, no denial of equal protection.

context.speaker: Mark B. Robinette
context.text: --I don't believe there was error.

context.speaker: Mark B. Robinette
context.text: I agree with Justice Scalia.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist

context.speaker: W. Gaston Fairey

context.text: But with Justice Kennedy's, you know the motive of the trial judge.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: So what is the answer that the appellate court gives?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist

Let me ask you this.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I mean, we're talking... what you're complaining about is something different.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the Court in No. 87-6325, Perry against Leeke will be announced by Justice Stevens.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: At the conclusion of petitioners direct testimony in his criminal trial, the judge declared a 15-minute recess and ordered the petitioner not be allowed to talk to anyone including his lawyer during the break.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit held that this order violated petitioners Sixth Amendment right to the assistance of counsel, but it also held that the conviction should stand because the order did not prejudice the petitioner.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: If a criminal defendants Sixth Amendment right to assistance of counsel has been violated because of a denial of access to counsel, then a conviction must be reversed without consideration of prejudice.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: However, we also hold that in this case, the denial of access to counsel during the 15-minute recess before cross-examination did not violate the Sixth Amendment.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Accordingly, we affirm the judgment of the Court of Appeals.

context.text: The effect of the Court of Appeals' mixed motive analysis, which basically awards the tie to the plaintiff in a case where you can't decide what the cause was.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, you tell us you don't like labels, but it seems to me we have to use labels at times in order to describe to District and trial courts what they should do, and that the answer you have just given to Justice O'Connor is that the Plaintiff must show "but for" causation.

context.speaker: Ms. Kathryn A. Oberly
context.text: If we need a label, that is the answer I would give.

context.speaker: Ms. Kathryn A. Oberly

context.text: Skinner is the first of two cases we decide today which concerns challenges to the constitutionality to the different drug testing programs.

Skinner v. Railway Labor Executives' Ass.speaker: Justice Kennedy
Skinner v. Railway Labor Executives' Ass.case_name: Skinner v. Railway Labor Executives' Association
Skinner v. Railway Labor Executives' Ass.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - MARCH 21, 1989

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The railroad Industry is subject to pervasive health and safety regulations and the affected employees already have consented to significant restrictions imposed by the employers.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: In light of the limited discretion exercised by the railroad employers under the regulations, the surpassing safety interests served by the test in this context and the diminished expectations of privacy that attached to information pertaining to the fitness of covered employees, we believe that it is reasonable to conduct such tests in the absence of the warrant or of suspicion that any particular employee maybe impaired.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: We hold that the alcohol and drug test contemplated by the regulations are reasonable within the meaning of the Fourth Amendment.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Justice Stevens has filed a separate opinion concurring in part and concurring in the judgment; Justice Marshall has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justice Brennan has joined.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Only If you know, only if you know I understood--

context.speaker: William Isaac Diggs
context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: William Isaac Diggs
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: --Justice Kennedy's question to be a random shot.

context.speaker: William Isaac Diggs
context.text: That... okay, I'm sorry.

context.speaker: William Isaac Diggs
context.text: I misunderstood that.

context.speaker: John M. Morris, III
context.text: You don't sentence someone to death because he is a nice person or a bad person.

context.speaker: John M. Morris, III
context.text: You sentence him because he has committed a murder and, incidentally, he did so out of full awareness of what's going on and knowledge of the consequences, or didn't, for that matter.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I don't understand.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Are you saying... perhaps it's the same thing Justice Marshall asked that the particular character of the offender has nothing to do with the degree of culpability?

context.speaker: John M. Morris, III
context.text: No, Your honor.

context.speaker: John M. Morris, III
context.text: In fact, I'm saying the contrary, I'm saying--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But you're not talking here about responsibility, it seems to me.

context.speaker: Nancy A Mckerrow
context.text: No, Your Honor, we're not talking about the fact that a 16-year-old child cannot act with criminal responsibility.

context.speaker: Nancy A Mckerrow
context.text: Petitioner's argument is that no 16-year-old can act with the level of moral culpability which should be required by a society before that person is executed, and that we require the highest level of moral culpability and responsibility before we would execute a person for a crime committed.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: I think Justice Kennedy had a question for you.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: You indicated that the legislature was waiting for this Court's guidance.

context.speaker: Nancy A Mckerrow
context.text: Yes, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: But 2412(d)(3) is significant in our view because it is a provision of the Act that specifically addresses the circumstances in which a court may award fees... in which a court may award fees for services performed before an agency.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: And 2412(d)(3) is specifically limited to those cases in which the party seeks judicial review of an adversary adjudication.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: In other words, the only case in which a court may award fees for work done before an agency, the very relief that Respondent seeks in this case, is, once again, when the agency itself has conducted an adversary adjudication in which the agency is represented by counsel.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: In the program, the pilot program that you described to Justice Scalia, would the attorney's fees... could attorney's fees be awarded in that instance, where these representatives of the government weren't present assuming other conditions are satisfied that the government's position is not substantially justified?

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: If there had been an attorney present in the experimental program?

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, yes.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: When a case is remanded back to the Agency, they are, again, Agency, or administrative proceedings--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Mr. Kneedler--

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: --not judicial proceedings.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: --would you respond to Justice Scalia's question about... would it be open to this Court, given the statutory scheme, to hold that your opponent became a prevailing party when the case was remanded?

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: No, it would not.

context.speaker: Edwin S. Kneedler
context.text: The legislative history on page 26 of our brief that we cite discusses--

context.speaker: Patricia Unsinn
context.text: The defense exercised one of its challenges against the remaining black juror... she was married to a police officer, and his client was charged with attempted murder of a police officer.

context.speaker: Patricia Unsinn
context.text: The result was that the petitioner was tried before a jury which was not representative of the community which was 25 percent black.

context.speaker: Patricia Unsinn
context.text: This case thus presents the question of whether the Sixth Amendment bars the prosecutor's use of the peremptory challenge to defeat the possibility that the petit jury will be representative of a fair cross section of the community.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Ms. Unsinn, may I interrupt you there to inquire whether... if this Court were to adopt the other part of Justice Harlan's view of retroactivity on collateral review, whether we would be able to reach your Sixth Amendment argument at all?

context.speaker: Patricia Unsinn
context.text: Yes, Judge, I believe you would because--

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Why?

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Why?

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: This comes to us on Federal habeas, right?

context.speaker: Patricia Unsinn
context.text: --Yes, Judge, but--

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: And under Justice Harlan's view, any new right recognized wouldn't be retroactive.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: And wouldn't we just be rendering an advisory opinion, then, on the Sixth Amendment question if we were to adopt that view?

context.speaker: Patricia Unsinn
context.text: --No, Justice O'Connor, we don't believe that we're proposing any new rule in our Sixth Amendment argument.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: At what point during the trial, Ms. Unsinn, does that happen?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: You say the defendant has to make some sort of a showing.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: At what point in the trial does that kind of thing happen?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: This is perhaps the follow up of Justice Kennedy's question.

context.speaker: Patricia Unsinn
context.text: --I would imagine whenever it became evident that the representative nature of, character of the jury was being impaired.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: And how would one know when that had happened?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the Court in number 87-1245 Texas Monthly, Inc. versus Bullock will be announced by Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Now this case is here from the Court of Appeals of Texas.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The question we have to decide is whether a Texas exemption of a religious periodical from Texas sales taxes promotes religion in violation of the establishment clause of the First Amendment.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The State Court struck down the tax as applied to non-religious periodicals and ordered the state to refund the tax paid by appellant plus interest.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The State Court of Appeals reversed holding that the exemption satisfied the tripartite test of our decision in Lemon v. Curtsman and therefore did not violate the Establishment Clause.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Our judgment reverses the judgment of the Texas Court of Appeals and holds that the exemption does violate the Establishment Clause.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.

Trans World Airlines, Inc. v. Independen.speaker: Justice Rehnquist
Trans World Airlines, Inc. v. Independen.case_name: Trans World Airlines, Inc. v. Independent Federation of Flight Attendants
Trans World Airlines, Inc. v. Independen.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - FEBRUARY 28, 1989

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the Court in number 87-548, TransWorld Airlines versus IFFA will be announced by Justice O'Connor.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: This case comes to us on certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eight Circuit.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: In May of 1986, a strike of TransWorld Airlines by its flight attendants, organized under the Independent Federation of Flight Attendants, ended up with the attendants' unconditional offer to return to work.

Trans World Airlines, Inc. v. Independen.speaker: Justice O'Connor
Trans World Airlines, Inc. v. Independen.case_name: Trans World Airlines, Inc. v. Independent Federation of Flight Attendants
Trans World Airlines, Inc. v. Independen.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - FEBRUARY 28, 1989

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Our decision, as explained in the opinion, rest on our understanding of the Railway Labor Act, the statute which governs labor management relations in the airline industry, and its close relative, the National Labor Relations Act.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: We hold today that TWA's decision to replace senior striking employees with junior non-striking employees and its refusal to displace them at the conclusion of the strike was an exercise of TWA's peaceful economic power that it was legally free to deploy.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Once labor and management had exhausted the private dispute resolution mechanisms of the Railway Labor Act.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Justice Brennan has filed a dissenting opinion in which Justice Marshall has joined.

context.speaker: Sandra Day O'Connor
context.text: Justice Blackmun has filed a dissenting opinion in parts one and two of which Justice Brennan has joined.

context.speaker: Glenn E. Casebeer, III
context.text: All their procedures were under the conspiracy, and the only thing I can argue is the charges they brought, which were conspiracy.

context.speaker: Glenn E. Casebeer, III
context.text: If there was a conspiracy charge and an object charge, you don't have a double jeopardy problem and we're not--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I'm not sure that the two of you mean the same thing by in an object charge.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I think Justice Stevens means you can prosecute a separate, individual conspiracy.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You don't... that's not what you mean by an object.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: You mean if the object of the later conspiracy is to murder somebody, you can prosecute the murder, not the conspiracy to murder.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Now, do... do you think the district court could impose a fine of $1 million in a case like this in a criminal prosecution?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: The only issue would be whether it violated the Eighth Amendment, the excessive fines or cruel and unusual punishment provision.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: But this was not a criminal prosecution.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: And I think, Justice White, in response to one of your earlier questions, the district court's holding isn't necessarily that this penalty can only be imposed in a criminal prosecution.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: What the district court did was recognize that when the defendant had been punished once--

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Why did he say this was a criminal prosecution?

United States v. Ron Pair Enterprises, I.speaker: Justice White
United States v. Ron Pair Enterprises, I.case_name: United States v. Ron Pair Enterprises, Inc.
United States v. Ron Pair Enterprises, I.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - OCTOBER 31, 1988

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: What about a, what about a seller of goods who delivers the goods and the payment is due, and it is not paid, and there's no provision in the contract for interest, and then the buyer goes into bankruptcy, and interest... if you had gone to court, the... no doubt that you would have gotten prejudgment interest.

context.speaker: I. William Cohen
context.text: If the law of the jurisdiction, Your Honor, gave you interest--

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Well, it doesn't?

context.speaker: Byron R. White
context.text: Isn't it... as Justice Scalia asked you, isn't it normally that courts give you interest up to the date of judgment?

context.speaker: I. William Cohen
context.text: --Yes, but it's different here, and the reason that it's different is because this Court has seen fit to say on many occasions that interest stops on the date of bankruptcy.

context.speaker: I. William Cohen
context.text: In the New York v. Saper case this Court--

context.speaker: Robert P. Goldberg
context.text: The court was divided, Your Honor, on that.

context.speaker: Robert P. Goldberg
context.text: I believe the... I'm sorry... my understanding of Royer was that Royer was determined... Royer was finally determined on the small room where, in fact, it was an arrest, even though it was not--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: That's right.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And as Justice O'Connor indicates, we stated quite clearly that cash, travelling under an assumed name, etcetera, was grounds for the initial stop and interrogation.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The plurality opinion so indicated.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And that's all we're dealing with here.

context.speaker: Robert P. Goldberg
context.text: And in looking at the totality of the circumstances they determined that... and even this case the government says quite... in their brief they say the way a person is dressed and his age... of course, being under 35 is half our population... is not really something to be considered very strongly.

context.speaker: Robert P. Goldberg
context.text: Considered, yes, but not very strongly.

context.speaker: Robert P. Goldberg
context.text: All of which is indicative of innocent behavior.

context.speaker: Harry A. Blackmun
context.text: --Well, maybe Justice Kennedy can help me out.

context.speaker: Robert P. Goldberg
context.text: Possibly.

context.speaker: Robert P. Goldberg
context.text: Justice Kennedy, I believe, was sitting at the time the Ninth Circuit made their decision.

context.speaker: Lawrence G. Wallace
context.text: Congress has left that holding in Donaldson entirely untouched for the category of third-party records that was involved there, employer records or records of a former employer.

context.speaker: Lawrence G. Wallace
context.text: There is... that is still good law.

context.speaker: Lawrence G. Wallace
context.text: The taxpayer cannot even be heard during the summons enforcement proceeding.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And I'm somewhat puzzled, however, because in your answer to Justice Scalia's question, you said well, the IRS does make... give itself some assurance that the other country is acting in good faith, yet I thought that's exactly what you're telling us we can't require you to do.

context.speaker: Lawrence G. Wallace
context.text: You can... in the summons enforcement proceeding, the question is the IRS' good faith rather than the--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I understand that that's your position.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Which of those?

context.speaker: Charles E. Peery
context.text: Well, we... we not only have problems of differences in countries' approach to these matters, but differences in language, and what... I think that a treaty partner asking us for information in this country ought to educate themselves about the difference between prosecution and investigation and should be able to comply with that request.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, what... in this country it's one function is in one division and another function is in another division.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But as Justice Scalia points out, in a country where they don't have that separation of functions, the, the question really would be very difficult to answer, I would think.

context.speaker: Charles E. Peery
context.text: Well, I believe it is.

context.speaker: Charles E. Peery
context.text: There are difficulties in administering treaties, but the focus here, as these cases arise procedurally and come before this Court is that the courts of this country, the federal district court in this case is being asked to lend its process and its authority to the enforcement of a summons to get information from another country under a treaty which specifically refers to the domestic revenue laws of the United States.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: The opinion of the Court in number 87-1064, United States against Stuart will be announced by Justice Brennan.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: This case is here on certiorari to the Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: Articles 19 and 21 of the 1942 Convention respecting double taxation between the United States and Canada require the United States on request and consistent with the United States revenue laws to obtain and convey information to Canadian authorities to assist them in determining a Canadian taxpayer's income tax liability.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: It must determine that Revenue Canada's investigation has not reached the stage analogous to a justice department referral by the IRS that here, the affidavit submitted by the IRS failed to state that such a determination had been made with respect to revenue Canada's investigation of respondents.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We reverse the judgment of the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We hold that neither the 1942 Convention nor domestic legislation requires the IRS to attest that the Canadian tax investigation has not reached the stage analogous to a Justice Department referral by the IRS in order to obtain enforcement of a summons issued pursuant to a request by Canadian authorities under the convention.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: And what--

context.speaker: Alan I. Horowitz
context.text: --In the discretion of the court.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: --And what is your position?

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Because I think I have the same difficulty Justice Scalia did in reading your brief.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: You seem to be saying they don't really need anything.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: But I think you've kind of acknowledged they need something.

context.speaker: Michael Lee Hertzberg
context.text: It should not be the communication itself because otherwise, in the first instance, a party... whether it be the government or an adverse civil litigant... could come into court and just ritualistically intone the terms crime-fraud with respect to privileged communications, and under the scenario which the government outlines--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: No.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I think you're leaving out a step.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I think Justice Scalia and I are both assuming that without just coming into court and referring to the privilege the government has legitimately acquired possession of a privileged communication which it had a right to look at.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Could it then go ahead and ask the judge also to look at it to make this determination?

context.speaker: Michael Lee Hertzberg
context.text: --It should not be able to.

Volt Information Sciences, Inc. v. Board.speaker: Justice Rehnquist
Volt Information Sciences, Inc. v. Board.case_name: Volt Information Sciences, Inc. v. Board of Trustees, Leland Stanford Junior University
Volt Information Sciences, Inc. v. Board.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 30, 1988

context.speaker: James E. Harrington
context.text: There would be an argument there that perhaps that should be held unenforceable because... by... because the parties may not really have known what they were doing in, in adopting a body of law that had the effect of nullifying their agreement to arbitrate and that that fact might have offended the federal policy again favoring the arbitration of private disputes.

context.speaker: James E. Harrington
context.text: Turning then to a second and considerably broader rationale which might be used to uphold the Court's jurisdiction, I would submit to the Court that the... the choice-of-law issue resolved by the court of appeal, besides being dependent on federal law in the way I've mentioned and in the various other ways we've described in our briefs, was itself a pure question of federal law in the... in the last analysis because the issue ultimately decided by the court was the inherently federal question of whether federal law should apply to this case.

context.speaker: James E. Harrington
context.text: And, and this Court has often stated that the issue of whether federal law applies to a particular case is, is itself always a federal question.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: So, if the parties deliberately exclude federal law, as they have in Justice Kennedy's hypothesis... they say the arbitration shall be governed by the California Code of Civil Procedure... that becomes a federal question?

context.speaker: James E. Harrington
context.text: Oh, no.

context.speaker: James E. Harrington
context.text: No, because there, there I don't think the, the Court ever faces the... that's a clear... as I conceded in response to Justice Kennedy's question, I don't think the question would even be argued or presented that that clause... that the interpretation of that clause would lead to an application of federal law.

Volt Information Sciences, Inc. v. Board.speaker: Justice Rehnquist
Volt Information Sciences, Inc. v. Board.case_name: Volt Information Sciences, Inc. v. Board of Trustees, Leland Stanford Junior University
Volt Information Sciences, Inc. v. Board.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - NOVEMBER 30, 1988

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: But, but... give me again then the situation where you say it does present a federal question.

context.speaker: James E. Harrington
context.text: Well, our case where it says law of the place where the project is located.

context.speaker: James E. Harrington
context.text: Additionally, a case in which--

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Well, why is that different legally from Justice Kennedy's hypothesis?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Each of them is trying to state the agreement of the parties about what law shall govern their, their contract or their arbitration.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: One chooses one set of words, another chooses another more precise set of words.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Thank you Mr. Susman.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: General Webster, do you have rebuttal?

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: You have two minutes remaining.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: While you are getting ready, General Webster, I would like you to answer Justice Scalia's question whether in the funding provision, the funding officer would have a duty to promulgate regulations that would prevent a doctor, a state employee from performing abortions and the like.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I think you heard the colloquy earlier.

context.speaker: William L. Webster
context.text: Turning first to your question, Your Honor, we have suggested all along that the language relating to funding only directs and only goes to those officers of public funding.

Will v. Michigan Department of State Pol.speaker: Justice Scalia
Will v. Michigan Department of State Pol.case_name: Will v. Michigan Department of State Police
Will v. Michigan Department of State Pol.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - DECEMBER 05, 1988

context.speaker: George H. Weller
context.text: If you feel--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: And this is a case, is it not, that was, in either law or equity, commenced against one of the United States by a, by a citizen?

context.speaker: George H. Weller
context.text: --I believe, Your Honor, the history of this Court and the cases involved show that in order to ensure the supremacy of federal law... Corens, for example, v. Virginia requires that this Court entertain these actions, if it chooses to do so, of course, on certiorari, but it has jurisdiction to hear appeals on federal causes of action coming from state courts to determine, and analyze and determine whether the federal law does or does not apply.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Gee, I don't know why you don't rely on the 11th Amendment, because... if the 11th Amendment did apply to us as well as to other Federal courts, and as Justice Kennedy points out there's nothing that says it doesn't, then what your opponent would be suggesting is that Congress created federal causes of action in state courts against the states, they couldn't be appealed to the United States Supreme Court, so there'd be no way of, of giving any unity to that particular Federal law.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: That wouldn't be a very sensible arrangement, would it?

context.speaker: George H. Weller
context.text: I don't believe this is a valid argument, Your Honor, that a, a... the interpretation of a federal statute, by a state court, interpreting the meaning of a federal statute, cannot be appealed to this Court.

context.speaker: Michael Douglas White
context.text: That's correct.

context.speaker: Michael Douglas White
context.text: And it certainly doesn't measure what Congress may have had in mind for the... for the agricultural needs of that reservation.

context.speaker: Michael Douglas White
context.text: That--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But as I understand... as I understand Justice Scalia's question and your answer, you would fix in this decree for all time the amount of water to which the Indians are entitled based on your present understanding of congressional intent?

context.speaker: Michael Douglas White
context.text: --We would fix it based on what Congress said, Your Honor.

context.speaker: Michael Douglas White
context.text: Not our understanding, but what they said in 1905, in the 1905 Act Water Proviso.

context.text: I have the opinions of the Court to announce in two cases, a number 87-1104 Zant versus Moore.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Justice Brennan has filed a concurring opinion.

context.speaker: William H. Rehnquist
context.text: Justice Blackmun has filed a dissenting opinion.
